They shall be sloped to maintain the street drainage in the street and to provide safe and convenient ingress and egress. Driveways shall be located to provide adequate sight distance. c. Commercial drives shall be constructed with a minimum six inches of concrete or asphalt pavement. Residential drives shall be constructed with a minimum four inches of concrete. Driveways shall be maintained by the property owner. (d) Deceleration lanes. Deceleration lanes shall be required on major roads and on collector roads with speed limits of 35 mph or higher. Deceleration lanes shall be 150 feet long with an additional 50-foot taper. The width shall be 12 feet from edge of pavement of through lane to edge of pavement of deceleration lane. Curb and gutter is required for the deceleration lane where the existing or proposed future construction of the road includes curb and gutter. The pavement structure shall meet the city's street paving requirements. Where a street is under the jurisdiction of the Georgia Department of Transportation (DOT), the owner/developer shall comply with the requirements of the DOT for deceleration lanes unless the city's requirements are stricter. (e) Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with the city's transportation plan or as required by the city's subdivision regulations. Construction of sidewalks and curb ramps shall meet the city's development standards and the Americans with Disabilities Act. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-5, 5-20-96) Secs. 74-36—74-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS AND OBSTRUCTIONS
Sec. 74-61. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person under any pretext whatever to make or place an excavation, embankment or obstruction in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way in the city until written application has been made for a permit from the city manager authorizing the same; except, that in the event an emergency exists where the health and safety of the citizens of the city are in danger, or for the immediate preservation of property, an excavation, embankment or obstruction may be made to the extent of abating the dangerous condition or situation; provided, upon relieving the existing emergency, the person making the excavation shall notify the city manager and otherwise comply with the requirements of this chapter regulating same. The issuance of a permit is not an affirmative assumption by the city to supervise or ensure the permittee complies with all requirements. Failure of permittee to comply will not be grounds for any actions against the city for negligence in issuing the permit. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-7, 5-20-96) State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10. Sec. 74-62. - Application for permit; issuance. Each application for a permit under section 74-61 shall describe the character of the work to be done, a full description of the premises where such work is to be done and shall be signed by the person applying for the permit. The permit shall be issued in duplicate, the original to be delivered to the party applying therefor, and one copy to be filed in the office of the city manager together with the application. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-8, 5-20-96) Sec. 74-63. - Permit conditions. The conditions of the permit required herein are as follows: (1) That the permittee will perform all work in a good and workmanlike manner in strict accordance with the provisions of this chapter; (2) That the permittee will backfill any excavations in any streets, alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways in the city, so as to return the same to their original condition; (3) That the permittee will place and maintain lights and barricades [and/or] guardrails around all excavations, materials or equipment left in any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place of the city; and (4) That the permittee will hold the city harmless from all damages, real or asserted, that may occur by reason of the operation. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-9, 5-20-96) Sec. 74-64. - Restoration of surface. When any part of any street, avenue, alley or public easement in the city shall be excavated, torn, dug or taken up for any purpose or when an embankment or obstruction is placed thereon, the person doing the same shall, immediately upon the completion of such purpose, and within at least ten days after the completion of such purpose, backfill and compact the same to a firm and solid bearing and in such manner as will entirely prevent the settling of such earth, and shall also relay the paving in a skillful and permanent manner, and in every case, to the satisfaction of the city manager. Failure to comply with the requirements of this section shall constitute an offense, and each day such failure continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-10, 5-20-96) Sec. 74-65. - Lights and barricades. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation, embankment or obstruction of whatsoever kind in the city, whether the same be in, along or near any street or sidewalk, alley or other public way of any kind, without placing proper barricades and signal lights or other warnings, at, in or around the same, sufficient to warn the public of such excavation, embankment or obstruction and to protect all persons using reasonable care from accident on account of the same. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-11, 5-20-96) Sec. 74-66. - Damaging streets, etc.; removing dirt. No person shall cut down or destroy any embankment or other improvement of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways. No person shall be allowed to dig or haul any dirt from any of the streets or alleys of the city without written permission from the city. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-12, 5-20-96) Secs. 74-67—74-95. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STREET LIGHTING DISTRICTS
Sec. 74-96. - Purpose. The City of Fayetteville desires to create street lighting districts designed to provide illumination for the streets of participating subdivisions and commercial districts. The City of Fayetteville desires to establish a mechanism whereby residents, or commercial establishments in the City of Fayetteville may elect to establish street lighting districts and to provide for a mechanism for approval of street lighting districts and a method for the billing of cost of said districts. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-16, 5-20-96) Sec. 74-97. - Established; objective. The City of Fayetteville hereby establishes street lighting districts within the city limits of the City of Fayetteville to illuminate public streets of participating subdivisions and commercial districts. It is not the objective of a street lighting district to illuminate private property. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-16(a), 5-20-96) Sec. 74-98. - Procedures for establishing. (a) The procedures for establishing street lighting districts shall be administered by the city manager, or his designee. (b) A street lighting district shall be established according to the standard practices of the power company which provides power services to that particular district. The district will utilize existing power poles, when possible; however, where there are underground power utilities, the owners or developer will be responsible for the cost of purchasing and placing of poles which meet the requirements of the city and the requirements of the respective power company. (c) The establishment of all street lighting districts shall be subject to the approval of the power company providing electrical services to the particular district. (Ord. No. 0-18-96, § 20-16(b)—(d), 5-20-96) Secs. 74-99—74-125. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82.
Sec. 74-126. - Permit required. No procession or parade of any number of persons, delegation or association of persons, or any company, circus or group shall march, drill parade on foot or in vehicles or on animals upon any public street, alley, highway or right-of-way without first having obtained a written permit from the police chief or his/her designee. (Ord. No. 0-28-92, § 17-5, 11-2-92; Ord. No. 0-33-95, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-127. - Exceptions. Funeral processions, the United States military forces and the military forces of this state are exempt from acquiring this permit for a parade. (Ord. No. 0-28-92, § 17-5(c), 11-2-92; Ord. No. 0-33-95, 9-18-95) Sec. 74-128. - Application. The permittee must furnish the police chief or his/her designee with the following information 30 days prior to the parade: (a) The name, address and contact numbers of the sponsor and persons organizing the event; (b) The name and contact numbers of the person who will be the parade leader and will be present at the event; (c) The selection of the particular council approved parade route to be used; (d) The date when the event is to be conducted; (e) The time at which units of the event will begin to assemble at any assembly area or areas; (f) The time the event is expected to depart and the time it is expected to stop; (g) Estimated number of participants; (h) Confirmation that approval has been obtained from any private property owner that may be effected by the event; and (i) Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. (Ord. No. 0-28-92, § 17-5(b), 11-2-92; Ord. No. 0-33-95, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-129. - Fees. The chief of police or his/her designee shall require the applicant to pay a fee to defray the costs to the city for police officers and other city staff. The fee shall be determined by the particular parade route selected by applicant. The city council shall adopt by resolution the fee for each parade route. The applicant shall be notified of the fee associated with the parade upon review of the application and selection of the parade route. The permit shall not be issued until the fees are paid. (Ord. No. 0-28-92, § 17-5(a), 11-2-92; Ord. No. 0-33-95, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-130. - Standards for issuance. The chief of police or his/her designee shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from consideration of the application and from any other information as may be otherwise be obtained, he finds that: (a) The conduct of the event will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; (b) The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; (c) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of areas contiguous to the assembly areas; (d) The conduct of the event will not unreasonably interfere with the movement of emergency equipment en route to a call: (e) The conduct of the event is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property; (f) The event is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-131. - Notice of denial. The chief of police or his/her designee shall act upon the application for a parade permit within five business days after the filing. If the application is denied, notification should be mailed to the applicant within two days after the date upon which the application was denied. The notification should include the reason(s) for the denial of the permit. The communication should be sooner if the date for the event requires a quicker response. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-132. - Appeal of denial. The denial by the police chief, or his/her designee, of an application for a parade permit may be appealed to the to the city manager by a written notice of appeal delivered to the clerk of the council within ten days of the date of the denial. The city manager shall immediately notify the mayor of any such appeal, and the mayor shall appoint himself or herself or a council member to hear the appeal along with the city manager. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-133. - Limitations on parade. (a) No procession or parade may be conducted or occur within the city between half-hour after sunset to half-hour before sunrise. (b) No procession or parade, unless sponsored by the Fayette County School System, shall proceed within 100 yards of a school during school hours or within one hour before the scheduled start of school or one hour after the scheduled end of school. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-134. - Notice to city and other officials. Upon issuance of a parade permit, the chief of police or his/her designee shall send a copy thereof to the fire chief and any other city department which may be affected. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-135. - Duties of permittee. (a) A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances of the state and this city. (b) Possession of permit. The parade leader or other person heading or leading the activity shall carry the parade permit upon his or her person during the conduct of the parade. (c) The parade leader shall not allow participants in the parade to throw any objects (to include candy) towards observers of the event. (d) The parade leader shall be responsible for informing all event participants the requirement of leaving no gaps in the procession. Large gaps in the procession are cause for termination. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-136. - Public conduct during parades. (a) Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. (b) Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when the vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. (c) Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to the effect, and it shall be unadvisable for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for standing or parking on a street unposted in violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-137. - Revocation of permit. The chief of police or his/her designee shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon violation of the conditions and directions attached to the permit. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06) Sec. 74-138. - Approved parade routes. Applicants shall be required to follow a pre-determined parade route previously approved by city council, and shall be required to choose one of the approved routes at the time of application. The approved council routes and the corresponding fees shall be established by resolution of the city council and may be changed from time to time by resolution of the council as may be needed to accommodate changing road conditions or traffic patterns. The previously approved parade routes shall not apply to regional processions sanctioned by the state, the federal government, or agencies thereof. Applicants shall select from one of the following types of parade routes: (a) Regular route. Permits motor vehicles, noise making devices, sound amplification devices or musical instruments (subject to other laws). (b) Silent route. No motor vehicles, noise making devices, sound amplification devices or musical instruments permitted. (c) Right-of-way processions. Procession is permitted on sidewalks and right-of-ways only. No motor vehicles, noise making devices, sound amplification devices or musical instruments permitted. (Ord. No. 0-7-06, arts. 1, 2, 6-1-06)

div.head: Chapter 78 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Planning and zoning commission, § 2-166 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; zoning, ch. 94.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 78-1. - Interpretations. (a) Except as specifically defined herein, all words in this resolution have their customary dictionary definitions. The Fayetteville City Council's interpretation shall be final as to the meaning of any definition, statement, requirement, symbol, and/or abbreviation used in connection with these regulations and/or application thereof. (b) Words in the present tense include the future tense. Words in the singular include the plural, and words in the plural include the singular. (c) The word "shall" is always mandatory and never discretionary. (d) The word "person" includes individuals, firms, partnerships, corporations, associations, governmental bodies, and all other legal entities. (e) The word "street" includes streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, highways, expressways, lanes, alleys and other vehicular ways. (f) The word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel." The word "building" includes the word "structure." (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 200, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-2. - Definitions. For the purpose of these regulations, certain terms or words used herein shall be defined as follows: Alley or service drive means a public right-of-way not intended to be a vehicular arterial or to provide the primary means of access to abutting property but which is used for service access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting a public street, and which may be used for public utility purposes. Building line means a line beyond which no foundation wall or part of the structure of any building shall project, with the exception of roof overhang and the subsurface projection of footings; provided, however, that such overhang and footings do not encroach upon the adjacent property or right-of-way. City means the City of Fayetteville, Georgia. Unless otherwise specified, these rules and regulations refer to all land lying within the corporate limits of Fayetteville as now or hereafter established. City council means the mayor and city council of the City of Fayetteville, Georgia. City engineer means the official or consulting engineer whom the city has delegated the responsibilities normally associated with this title. City manager as used herein includes the office of the city manager, and as such may include the building inspector, city clerk or other persons designated by the city manager to act on behalf of the city. City planner means the official to whom the city has delegated the responsibilities normally associated with this title. Clerk of the superior court means the clerk of the superior court of Fayette County, Georgia. Commissioner of health means the Fayette County Health Department and/or the State of Georgia Department of Health. The words "commissioner of health" are used in these regulations to denote the fact that all matters pertaining to health regulations shall be directed to that official or his staff. Common walk means a right-of-way, dedicated to common use, with a paved sidewalk, providing pedestrian access between dwelling units and such common use facilities as schools, parking lots, shopping centers, recreation areas and other community facilities. Comprehensive plan means the official comprehensive plan of the City of Fayetteville. County means Fayette County, Georgia. Cul-de-sac means a street having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated within the plat by a vehicular turnaround. Easement means a grant by the property owner for the use by the public, a corporation, or persons of a strip of land for specific purposes. Engineering plan means finished detailed design drawings and engineering data for the subdivision showing completely and accurately the horizontal and vertical details of utilities, roads, storm drainage, and other physical improvements which will support the subdivision. Final plat means a finished drawing of the subdivision showing completely and accurately all legal and engineering information and certification necessary for recording. Land subdivision means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of legacy or building development; including all division of land involving a new street to which the public has access or a change in an existing street, and including resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: (1) The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards of these regulations. (2) The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved. (3) Division or sale of land by judicial decree shall not be deemed a division for purposes of this chapter. Lot means a portion of a subdivision, or any other parcel of land identified by a tract number, lot number, or symbol on an approved subdivision plat properly recorded, and which is or may in the future be offered for sale, conveyance, transfer or improvement. In determining the area and dimensions of a lot, no part of the right-of-way of a road or common walk may be included. Planning commission means the planning and zoning commission of the City of Fayetteville, Georgia. Plat means a map indicating the subdivision or resubdivision of land, intended to be filed for record. Preliminary plat means a drawing which shows the proposed layout of the property lines, rights-of-way, easements, buffer zones and building setback lines of a subdivision in sufficient detail to indicate unquestionably its workability, but which is not in final form for recording and the details are not completely computed. Right-of-way means a portion of land being used or which in the future will be used as a street, road, thoroughfare, crosswalk, pipeway, drainage canal, and/or other similar uses and designated by means of right-of-way lines. Street means a dedicated and accepted right-of-way for vehicular traffic whether designated as highway, thoroughfare, lane, intended to distinguish between different categories of streets: (1) Major street means a street which is designated as such in the zoning ordinance and which is intended to provide swift and safe movement of traffic through the community. (2) Collector street means a street which is designated as such in the zoning ordinance and which is intended to collect traffic from minor streets and direct it safely to major streets. (3) Commercial street means a street serving primarily commercial developments. (4) Dead-end street means a street having only one end open for access to another street, the other end being abruptly terminated with no turnaround. (5) Marginal access street means a street parallel to and adjacent to a major thoroughfare or secondary street providing access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. (6) Minor street means a street which is designated as such and which is used for local circulation in residential areas providing access to abutting property. (7) Industrial street means a street serving primarily industrial developments. (8) Alley means a minor vehicular way providing service access to the back or sides of properties abutting a street. Subdivider means the person having sufficient proprietary interest in the land to be subdivided to authorize the maintenance of proceedings to subdivide such land under these subdivision regulations, or the authorized agent of that person for the purpose of such proceeding. Subdivision. See Land subdivision. Subdivision regulations. The subdivision regulations ordinance [this chapter] of the City of Fayetteville, Georgia. Through or double-frontage lot means a lot having frontage on two streets that are approximately parallel. Transportation plan means the map, plan, and or document adopted by the city council indicating the transportation system improvements needed within the city to accommodate future growth. Utility means any community service available to the public by means of an overhead or underground distribution or collection system such as electricity, telephone, water, gas, and sewage disposal. Zoning ordinance means the zoning ordinance enacted by the city council of Fayetteville, Georgia. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 201, 9-3-96) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 78-3. - Enactment clause. The mayor and city council of Fayetteville, Georgia, under the authority conferred by the State of Georgia, hereby ordains and enacts into law the articles and sections in this chapter. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 100, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-4. - Short title. These regulations shall be known and may be cited as the "Subdivision Regulations of Fayetteville, Georgia." (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 101, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-5. - Jurisdiction. These regulations shall govern the use of all land and developments thereof within the corporate limits of the City of Fayetteville. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 102, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-6. - Purpose. The purpose of these regulations shall be to promote the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare and to require the harmonious, orderly, and progressive development of land within the jurisdiction of Fayetteville. Further, the purpose of the regulation of the subdivision of land are, among others: (1) To encourage the development of economically sound and stable communities; (2) To assure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to new land developments; (3) To assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in new land developments; (4) To assure the provision of needed open spaces and building sites in new land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, and other public purposes; and (5) To assure, in general, the wise developments of new areas in harmony with the comprehensive plan of Fayetteville. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 103, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-7. - Violations and penalties. (a) Any person, firm or corporation or other legal entity violating any of the provisions of this resolution shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction, shall be punished for each offense according to the codes and ordinances of the City of Fayetteville. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (b) The city or any owner of real estate who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action in proceeding to stop the violation. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 703, 9-3-96) Secs. 78-8—78-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - VARIANCES, APPEALS, ADOPTION AND AMENDMENT
Sec. 78-36. - Powers of the planning and zoning commission to allow variances. (a) The following provisions shall apply to variances: (1) Requests for variances from these subdivision regulations shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission pursuant to the following powers and procedures: a. A written application for a variance as approved and provided by the city shall be submitted to the commission indicating the section of this chapter under which the variance is sought, and stating the grounds upon which it is requested. b. Before making its decision on a request, the commission shall hold a public hearing thereon. c. At the expense of the applicant, the commission shall give public notice of a hearing on a variance in the newspaper used as the official legal organ for the City of Fayetteville, published at least 15 days, but not more than 45 days prior to the date of the hearing, and shall further cause the erection at least 15 days prior to the date of the hearing, in a conspicuous place on the property in question, a sign as a notice to the public that a petition for a variance has been filed as to the property and that a public hearing will be held on the request before the planning and zoning commission, stating the date, time and place of that hearing. d. The applicant or any aggrieved party may appear at the public hearing in person or by agent. e. The commission shall reach a decision by their next regular scheduled meeting. f. Decision of the planning and zoning commission with regard to the grant of variance may be reviewed by the city council pursuant to section 78-37 of this subdivision regulation. g. The variance shall expire at the time the plans for which the variance was granted expires. (2) Criteria for granting of variance. The commission may authorize, in specific cases, such variance from the terms of these regulations as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of these regulations will, in an individual case, result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of these regulations shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. Such variance may be granted, in an individual case, upon a finding by the commission that the following exists: a. There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question, because of its size, shape or topography; and b. The application of these regulations to this particular piece of property would create a practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship; and c. Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and d. Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of these regulations; and e. A literal interpretation of this chapter would deprive the applicant of any rights that others in the same district are allowed; however f. Provided that the commission may impose or require such additional restrictions and standards as may be necessary to protect the health and safety of workers and residents in the community, and to protect the value and use of property in the general neighborhood; and provided that wherever the commission shall find, in the case of any permit granted pursuant to the provisions of these regulations, that any of the terms, conditions, or restrictions upon which such permit was granted are not complied with, said commission shall rescind and remove such permit after giving due notice to all parties concerned and granting full opportunity for a public hearing. A variance will not be granted to relieve a landowner from a hardship that is self-created. (b) In exercising the above powers, the commission shall not consider any nonconforming use of the neighboring lands, structures or buildings in the same district and no permitted use of lands, structures, or buildings in other districts as grounds for the issuance of a variance. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 600, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-37. - Establishment of appeals process. (a) All appeals from actions of the city manager or the planning and zoning commission shall be heard by the mayor and city council during their regularly scheduled council meetings or at other times at the call of the mayor. The mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena. (b) Cases brought before the mayor and council shall be decided by majority vote of members present and voting. A quorum shall consist of three or more members. Any member may elect to abstain from any vote. An affirmative vote of at least three members is required to approve a petition. The appeal before the city council shall be de novo. The city council may publish its decision in writing within ten days of the vote. (c) The mayor and council shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be filed in the office of the city manager and shall be a public record. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 601, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-38. - Powers of the mayor and council to decide appeals. The mayor and council shall have the power to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the city manager or planning commission in the enforcement of this subdivision regulation ordinance [this chapter]. In exercising the above powers, the mayor and city council may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the orders, requirements, decisions, or determinations of the city manager or the planning and zoning commission. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 602, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-39. - Appeals to and reviews by the mayor and city council. (a) Persons aggrieved by a decision of the planning and zoning commission or by the city manager may appeal said decision to the mayor and city council by a written notice of appeal specifying the decision appealed from and the specific grounds for the appeal filed with the city clerk within ten days from the date of the decision of the city manager or the planning and zoning commission. Upon a notice of appeal being filed, the city manager shall forthwith transmit to the mayor and city council all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. Furthermore, within ten days of any decision of the planning and zoning commission or of the city manager, the city council may, by the concurrence of three members, call any decision of the planning and zoning commission or the city manager for review by it pursuant to the procedures for appeal set forth herein. (b) No permit shall be issued upon any decision of the planning and zoning commission or the city manager until ten days have passed from said decision, provided that no appeal is filed by the aggrieved person or the matter is not called for review by the city council. No permit shall issue on any decision of the planning and zoning commission or the city manager during the pendency of any appeal or review by the city council and until a final decision has been published by the city council. (c) An appeal stays all legal proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the city manager certifies to the mayor and council after the notice of appeals shall have been filed with him, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by a court of record on application, on notice to the city manager, and on due cause shown. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 603, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-40. - Appeals from decisions of mayor and city council. Any person or persons, or any board, taxpayer, department, or bureau of the city aggrieved by any decision of the mayor and city council may seek review by a court of record of such decision, in the manner provided by the laws of the State of Georgia. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 604, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-41. - Adoption of land subdivision regulations. Before the mayor and city council adopt this chapter or an amendment to it, the city shall hold a public hearing thereon, at least 15 days' notice of the time and place of which shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 605, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-42. - Amendments permitted. This subdivision regulation chapter may be amended from time to time by the city council of Fayetteville, Georgia. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 606, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-43. - Amendment procedure. The procedure for amending this subdivision chapter shall be as outlined below: (1) All amendments shall be proposed by or shall first be submitted to the planning commission for review and recommendation prior to adoption by the city council. The planning commission shall have 60 days within which to complete its review and submit a report and recommendations to the city council. During the 60-day review period, the planning commission may at its discretion hold a public hearing on the proposed amendment. Notice of the time and place of any such public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days and not more than 45 days prior to the hearing date. If the planning commission fails to submit a report to the city council within the 60-day review period, it shall be deemed to have approved the proposed amendment. (2) After the 60-day planning commission review period proposed amendments to this subdivision regulation chapter shall be submitted to the city council for adoption, modification or rejection. Before the city council acts on an amendment to these subdivision regulations, it shall hold a public hearing thereon, at least 15 days' notice of the time and place of which shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 607, 9-3-96) Secs. 78-44—78-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PLATS AND PLANS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 78-71. - Platting authority. (a) From and after the passage of this resolution, the planning and zoning commission and city council of the City of Fayetteville shall be the platting authority. Day-to-day administration of these subdivision regulations shall be the responsibility of the city manager. (b) No subdivision shall be accepted for review which does not conform with the zoning regulations applicable to the land for which it is proposed. (c) Any subdivider of land within the corporate limits of Fayetteville shall submit to the planning commission plats of the subdivision which shall conform to all requirements set forth in these regulations. (d) No subdivider shall proceed with any construction work on the proposed subdivision streets or utilities, including clearing and grading, before obtaining preliminary plat approval from the planning commission, as certified thereon, and approval of engineering plans by the city engineer. (e) No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the incorporated area of Fayetteville unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted or opened as, or shall have otherwise received the legal status of, a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a final plat approved by the city engineer or on a street located and accepted by the city. Also, the grading, drainage, gravel base, curb and gutter, water lines and fire protection components and sanitary sewer shall be constructed and functioning in a manner acceptable to the city (also reference chapter 74, Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Places, section 74-32). Provided, however, that private streets and other private accessways may be approved under the terms of these rules and regulations in group development plans, condominium projects, apartment projects, townhouses, commercial developments, shopping centers or other developments. (f) No land dedicated as a public street or other public purpose shall be opened, extended, or accepted as a public street or for any other purpose, and no subdivision of land shall be made, nor subdivision plat, nor part thereof, shall be recorded with the clerk of superior court, Fayette County, Georgia, before obtaining final plat approval from the city engineer. The city engineer shall not approve any subdivision plat without said plat having first been reviewed and approved by the health department to the extent that it has jurisdiction. (g) No street or utilities shall be accepted for maintenance until the approved final plat has been recorded with the clerk of superior court. No certificates of occupancy will be issued until the streets and utilities have been constructed and accepted for maintenance by the city council. (h) The filing or recording of a plat of a subdivision which has not been approved by the city engineer is hereby declared a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction, the person filing or recording such plat shall be punished as provided by law. The owner or the agent of the owner of any land to be subdivided in the incorporated area of the city who transfers or sells or agrees to sell or negotiates to sell land by reference to or exhibition or other use of a plat of a subdivision that is in basic conflict with the land subdivision plat of record that has been approved by the city and has been recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided by law; and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the selling or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. The city attorney of the city may enjoin such transfer or agreement by appropriate action. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 300, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-72. - Preapplication conference. Before proceeding with a proposed land subdivision, subdividers are invited and encouraged to consult early and informally with the city engineer, city planner and/or planning commission. The subdivider may submit sketch plans and data showing existing conditions within the site and in its vicinity and the proposed layout of the subdivision. No fee shall be charged for this review, and no formal application is necessary. The purpose of the preapplication conference is to afford the subdivider an opportunity to avail himself of the advice and assistance of the city in order to facilitate the subsequent preparation and approval of subdivision plans. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 301, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-73. - General contents of plats and plans. The subdivision plat and subdivision plan shall together present all of the legal and technical data required to confirm compliance with city ordinances and to allow recording of land ownership information. The plat is prepared to describe the layout of the property, including individual parcel boundaries, rights-of-way, easements, setbacks, and buffers and to identify the current property owner. The plan is prepared to describe the physical improvements, including pavements, utilities and storm drainage facilities which will be needed to support the proposed subdivision or land development. Preliminary plats, engineering plans and final plats will generally need to be presented as two separate documents. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 302, 9-3-96) Secs. 78-74—78-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT
Sec. 78-101. - Preliminary plat requirements. The preliminary land subdivision plat shall consist of a map or maps, drawn at a scale of not less than 100 feet to one inch, depicting the following: (1) The proposed name of the subdivision and proposed street names shall not duplicate or too closely approximate phonetically the name of any other subdivision or street in Fayette County. If shown to the contrary, the planning commission or E-911 center may refuse to accept such subdivision and street names. The subdivision may use letter designations in place of street names on the preliminary plat. (2) Name and address of the owner of record. (3) Name, address, and telephone number of the subdivider. (4) Date of survey, north point and graphic scale, source of data, date of plat drawing, and space for revision dates. (5) Preliminary plat certificates and statements as follows: a. Certificate of preliminary design. I hereby certify that the preliminary plat and layout of the proposed lots, block, streets, and other features included in this proposed preliminary plat have been prepared by me or under my direct supervision.
b. Certificate of preliminary plat approval. All requirements of the Fayetteville Subdivision Regulations relative to the preparation and submittal of a Preliminary Plat have been fulfilled, approval of this plat is hereby granted, subject to further provisions of said Regulations. This certificate shall expire ________ (date).
PRELIMINARY PLAT - NOT TO BE RECORDED (6) Location (land district and land lot), acreage, and lots. (7) A sketch locating the subdivision in relation to the surrounding area with regard to well-known landmarks such as major thoroughfares. Sketches may be drawn in freehand and at a scale sufficient to show clearly the information required, but not less than one inch to 2,000 feet. U.S. Geological Survey maps may be used as a reference guide for the location sketch. (8) Name of former subdivision if any or all of the preliminary plat had been previously subdivided. (9) Exact boundary lines of the tract indicated by a heavy line giving length and bearings, and total subdivision land area in acres. The boundary lines shall include the entire tract to be subdivided eventually and data as required herein shall apply to the entire tract. (10) Natural features within the proposed subdivision, including drainage channels, bodies of water, floodplain, wetlands and other significant features on site and off site. (11) Cultural features within the proposed subdivision, including right-of-way widths and names of existing and proposed streets, existing structures, all easements, buildings, city and county lines, land lot lines, zoning districts and lines, and other significant information. (12) Proposed layout including lot lines with rough dimensions, lot numbers, block letters, street and alley lines, minimum building setback lines, sites reserved through covenants, dedication or otherwise for public uses. (13) Proposed unit division or stage development, if any, as proposed by the subdivider. (14) The names of owners of record of adjoining land. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 400, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-102. - Preliminary plat and plan review. (a) The subdivider shall submit to the planning commission a letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat. Five copies of the preliminary plat must accompany the request, along with the preliminary plat review fees as specified by the city. (b) Submission of the preliminary plat is intended to assist the developer in clearly identifying features to be incorporated into the detailed design. The preliminary plat requires only approximate accuracy of scale and dimension. Public agencies having jurisdiction will review the preliminary submittal regarding matters within their jurisdiction and may call upon the subdivider for consultation. Street names shall be submitted to the E-911 center for approval prior to city approval. (c) The subdivider shall submit to the planning commission a reasonably accurate plat in sketch form of the entire tract which will show the tentative future layout for the entire tract. (d) An application for preliminary plat approval shall be studied by the planning commission for compliance with these regulations and with other relevant governmental and public utility company regulations. The planning commission will then conduct a public hearing with respect to the application at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the planning commission. Developers are encouraged to have a representative present to participate in the hearing process. The planning commission shall indicate on the plat or by written memorandum attached thereto, comments and any suggested changes that are necessary to meet the intent of these regulations or to serve the best interests of the city. (1) Within 60 days after the submission of an application for preliminary plat approval, the planning commission shall: a. Issue a certificate of preliminary plat approval; or b. Issue a certificate of conditional preliminary plat approval, subject to any necessary modifications the nature of which shall be indicated on the preliminary plat or attached to it in writing; or c. Disapprove the preliminary plat or any portion thereof in which case the planning commission shall so notify the subdivider in writing, stating the reasons therefor. (2) Action of the planning commission shall be noted on four copies of the preliminary plat. One copy shall be returned to the applicant, three made a part of the city's records. (3) Failure of the planning commission to take action on the preliminary plat within 60 days shall be deemed approval of the plat and a certificate of preliminary plat approval shall be issued to the subdivider at his request. (4) Approval of all preliminary plats shall be governed by the following qualifications: a. Approval of a preliminary plat is only tentative pending submission of the final plat and engineering plans. b. Approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective and binding upon the planning commission for a period not to exceed one year, and thereafter expire and be null and void unless a request for an extension of time has been submitted to and is subsequently approved by the planning commission. c. Tentative approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. It indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to the preparation of a final plat and engineering plans. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 303, 9-3-96) Secs. 78-103—78-125. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ENGINEERING PLANS
Sec. 78-126. - Engineering plan requirements. Engineering plans shall accurately describe the physical improvements required to support development of the subdivision. Drawings shall be prepared at a horizontal scale of not less than one inch to 100 feet and a vertical scale of not less than one inch equals ten feet. The information required on the engineering plans shall include the following: (1) Name and address of owner of record and subdivider and the name of the engineer responsible for preparation of the plans. (2) A written summary of the proposal giving information as to the overall development plan, giving types of structures, number or size of units, types of business or industry, and such other data as needed so that the effects of the development can be determined. (3) Contour lines based on sea level datum. These shall be drawn at intervals of not more than five feet. (4) Exact boundary lines of the subdivision by bearings and distances, and a scaled layout of lots and blocks with number and letter designations. (5) Location of existing buildings and other structures on the tract and any significant natural features, including trees to be preserved. (6) Date of the drawing, north point, graphic scale, and space for revision dates. (7) The following information related to water systems: a. An overall project map showing location of all water lines, valves, fire hydrants and other appurtenances relative to streets, lot lines, lot elevations, channels, structures and other project features significant to proposed water system improvements. b. Plan of water mains and appurtenances showing: 1. Stations at valves, intersections, and appurtenances. 2. Size and type or class of pipe and valves. 3. Distance from back of curb and/or from right-of-way. 4. Water line easements. 5. The location (above or below) storm sewers. 6. Location in relation to any parallel or crossing sanitary sewers. 7. Location and details of any proposed booster pumping station, pressure reducing station, backflow prevention equipment, or water storage tank. (8) Site grading and storm drainage information including the following: a. The 100-year flood limits and elevation. b. The watershed area in acres above the point of entry onto the site, and the acreage draining to any proposed stormwater detention facility, detention pond details, and hydrological study. c. The existing location or relocation of all streams that are not to be piped and all existing surface drainage structures with profiles as follows: 1. Profile of top of bank. 2. Profile of flow line of stream bed. 3. A detailed typical section and type of stabilization to be provided. 4. A floodplain study will be required of all land areas proposed for development which might be subject to flooding. 5. Setbacks required by the watershed protection ordinance, if any. 6. Location of wetlands and required setbacks, if any. d. The direction of drainage flow in streams, storm sewers, gutters, subdrains and the like. e. The location of all springs either within the right-of-way or draining to the right-of-way. f. The location of storm sewers and appurtenances, including: 1. Stations at every 100 feet and at appurtenances. 2. Catchbasins with proposed elevations for the tops and inverts. 3. All road crossings. 4. Outfalls of storm sewers to existing streams. g. Storm sewer profiles as follows: 1. Profile of existing ground at centerline of proposed storm sewer. 2. Profile of proposed finished grade. 3. Percent of grade of proposed storm sewer. h. All existing or proposed drainage easements. i. The size and type or class of drainage pipe to be installed both within and outside the road right-of-way. j. Proposed drainage ditches for the full length in all easements. Show centerline profiles, a detailed typical section and the type of stabilization to be provided when velocity exceeds three feet per second. k. Soil erosion and sedimentation control measures. Develop a plan in accordance with city ordinance. In the absence of such ordinance, in accordance to State of Georgia standards and requirements and with approval of city engineer. (9) Streets and appurtenances including the following information: a. Route number of any state highway to which a connection is to be made. b. Existing and proposed streets within a subdivision or in its immediate vicinity including: 1. Location. 2. Name. 3. Location of pavement edge, together with any existing or required surface water drainage pipes or other appurtenances. 4. Right-of-way with its location measured from the pavement centerline to the edge of the right-of-way. 5. Radius of all returns. 6. Stations at every 100 feet on the street centerlines. Also, stations at points of curvature and tangency, and at the beginning and end of all returns, at centerline intersections and at subdivision or construction limits. c. Road centerline curve data including deflection angle, radius, degree of curvature and tangent distance. At culs-de-sac, show grade profiles and design elevations around the entire turnaround. d. The profile of proposed street construction must include: 1. Percent of grade. 2. Design elevations at beginning and end of all vertical curves. 3. Length of vertical curves with design elevations and stations of vertical points of intersection. e. Existing roads to remain in use which abut or traverse the subdivision shall be shown, including the following: 1. Profiles. 2. Typical cross sections. 3. Any surface water drainage pipes and related appurtenances. f. (d) Final plat approval shall not be shown on the final plat until all requirements of these rules and regulations have been met and the city engineer has certified by endorsement on the plat that: (1) All improvements and installations to the subdivision required for its approval under the terms of these rules and regulations have been completed in accordance with the appropriate specifications; or (2) A cashiers check or cash deposit has been provided by the subdivider or developer to assure completion of required landscaping. No. 0-3-00, § 3, 2-7-00; Ord. No. 0-35-08, 11-20-08) Sec. 78-159. - Recording the final plat. (a) Upon final approval by the city the approved final plat with all endorsements and the declaration of covenants and restrictions (aka covenants) shall be recorded in the office of the Clerk of Superior Court, Fayette County, Georgia. Secs. 78-160—78-185. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION GUIDELINES
Sec. 78-186. - General principles of design. (a) Detailed specifications and requirements for development within the city are contained in the Fayetteville development standards and in this article. Where any conflict exists between the development standards and this chapter, the requirements of this chapter shall govern. Whenever there is a discrepancy between minimum standards noted herein and those contained in the zoning ordinance, building codes, or other ordinances of the city, county, or state, then the most restrictive shall apply. (b) Land subject to flooding, improper drainage or erosion, or land that is for topographical or other reasons unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use nor for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health and safety and of property destruction, unless the hazards can be and are corrected. (c) The subdivider shall preserve all trees and other natural growth as required by city ordinance. (d) Access to every subdivision and every lot within shall be provided over a public street. When land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged and designed so as to allow for the opening of future streets and to provide access to those areas not presently served by streets. (e) All proposed subdivisions shall conform to the development policies in effect at the time of submission to the planning commission. (1) All highways, streets, and other features of the transportation plan shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and to the dimension indicated on the master plan. In subdivisions related to or affecting any state or federally numbered highway, the approval of the Georgia State Highway Department may be required by the planning commission. (2) Where features of the transportation plan (other than minor streets and collector streets) such as school sites, parks, arterial streets, major thoroughfares, and other public spaces are located in whole or in part in a proposed subdivision, or when these features have not been anticipated by the master plan and planning policy, but are considered essential by the planning commission, such features shall be dedicated. The planning commission may waive these platting and reservation requirements whenever the public body responsible for land acquisition executes a written release stating that such a planned feature is not required. (3) Whenever the plat proposes the dedication of land to public use and the planning commission or the appropriate agency finds that such land is not required or suitable for public use, the planning commission may either refuse to approve said plat or it may require the rearrangement of lots to include such land. (f) The standards and requirements of these regulations may be modified in the case of a plan and program for group development projects or neighborhood unit or planned unit development which is not divided into customary lots, blocks, and streets, which, in the judgment of the planning commission, provides adequate public spaces and improvements for the circulation, recreation, light, air, and service needs of the tract when fully developed and populated, provided zoning density standards for the entire tract are not exceeded, and which also provides such covenants or other legal procedures as will assure conformity to and achievement of the plan. Plans for such developments shall be submitted to and approved by the planning commission whether or not such plat is to be recorded and no building permits shall be issued until such approval has been given. Normal review times may be extended to allow for thorough review and analysis of such development plans. (g) Modifications of the provisions set forth in these rules and regulations may be authorized by the planning commission in specific cases when, in its opinion, undue hardships may result from strict compliance; provided any such determination shall be based fundamentally on the fact that unusual topographical and other exceptional conditions require such modifications, and that the granting of the modifications will not adversely affect the general public or nullify the intent of these regulations; provided further that any such modification granted by the planning commission shall be made in writing to the subdivider and also made a part of the planning commission's records and the plat. Application for any modifications must be filed in writing with necessary supporting documents with the planning commission by the subdivider and shall explain in detail the reasons and facts supporting the application. (h) Permanent iron monuments (minimum one-half-inch rebar or three-fourths-inch pipe) at least by 16 inches long shall be accurately set and established at all corners of each lot. The accurate location, material, and size of all existing monuments shall be indicated on the final plat. (Ord. No. 0-40-96, § 500, 9-3-96) Sec. 78-187. - Street and right-of-way requirements. (a) The arrangements, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the transportation plan for the city and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. (b) Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. (c) Where a subdivision contains a dead-end street other than a cul-de-sac, the planning commission may require the subdivider to provide a temporary vehicular turnaround within the right-of-way, when the planning commission considers such to be necessary for effective traffic circulation. (d) Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major street, the planning commission may require marginal access streets, double-frontage lots with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property lines, deep lots with rear service drives, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. (e) Where a subdivision borders on or contains a limited access highway right-of-way, the planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. (f) The following street design standards shall be observed by the subdivider:
*Measured to back of curb. **Greater widths and more stringent criteria may be required. The minimum grade of all streets shall be 1.0 percent. (g) Where a subdivision abuts on an existing street, the subdivider shall dedicate additional right-of-way on said existing streets to meet the above minimum street width requirements from each side of the centerline. (h) Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible and no intersection shall be at an angle less than 70 degrees. Intersections shall be designed with a leveled area having a grade of not more than five percent for a distance of at least 60 feet, measured from the nearest right-of-way line of the intersecting street. (i) Streets within the subdivision shall be a projection of existing public streets. (j) Curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least 15 feet and where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, the planning commission may require a greater radius. (k) Right-of-way radius at street intersections shall parallel the curbline radius, or be metered from radius return point to radius return point. (l) Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. (m) Alleys or service drives may be required on any lots to be used for multiple-family, commercial or industrial developments, but shall not be provided in residential blocks. (n) Cul-de-sac streets shall have a maximum length of 2,000 feet as measured from the centerline of the intersecting street to the radius point of the cul-de-sac, including the circular turnaround, unless the total number of lots or dwelling units fronting on the cul-de-sac is less than 16. The planning commission is authorized to allow exceptions if conditions so justify at the time preliminary plat is submitted. (1) Temporary culs-de-sac may be required where the land adjoins property not subdivided. (2) If adjoining property contains a street that is terminated by a temporary cul-de-sac, the new subdivision plat may be required to provide for a continuation of this street on the property being developed. (o) Dead-end streets shall be prohibited. (p) The subdivider shall indicate on the subdivision plat the proposed name or number of all streets within the subdivision. Streets and roads that are obviously in alignment with and are extensions of existing previously named or numbered streets shall bear that name. The names of all new streets within the subdivision shall be subject to the approval of the planning commission. (q) Curbs and gutters shall be installed on all streets, except where noted herein. Installation shall be in accordance with the development standards of the City of Fayetteville. (r) The subdivider shall furnish all required sidewalks. Sidewalks shall have a minimum width of four feet and shall be provided under the following conditions: (1) Sidewalks are required on both of sides of all streets and shall be constructed, reconstructed or repaired as part of development work to meet the requirements of this chapter and of chapter 74, Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Plans. (2) The planning commission may require additional sidewalks and wider sidewalks within a distance of up to one mile on streets leading to or going through commercial areas, school sites, places of public assembly, and other congested areas. (3) In residential areas, provide a planting strip between the street curb and sidewalk. (4) Sidewalk must be completed before a certificate of occupancy can be issued. (5) City manager may require 100-percent completion of all sidewalks in a given route before issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (s) Guardposts or guardrails shall be provided when required for safety. (t) Major and collector streets shall be designed to AASHTO requirements. (u) Side slopes for streets shall not be steeper than two to one for cut or fill section. (v) Minimum pavement requirements include the following: MINIMUM PAVEMENT REQUIREMENTS
